question.title: Apache PDFBox uses ~1.6 GB RAM to render a 1-page scanned PDF — should I optimize Java or switch to PyMuPDF (Python)?
question.body:
I have a Java service that converts PDFs to images using Apache PDFBox.
For most text-based PDFs this works fine, but for some scanned, image-only PDFs, memory usage becomes extremely high.

metrics

Problem description

  • PDF: 1 page, scanned invoice

  • Content: single large embedded image (no text layer)

  • Operation: render PDF page to image

  • Library: Apache PDFBox

  • Result: ~1.6 GB peak memory usage for a single page

I’ve tested PyMuPDF (fitz) in Python, which renders the same document at 200–300 DPI using tens of MB, not hundreds or GBs.

Question

From a technical and architectural perspective:

  • Is it reasonable to continue using Java + PDFBox and try to optimize memory usage further?

  • Or is this a case where Python + PyMuPDF is fundamentally better suited for scanned/image-heavy PDFs?

  • When it makes sense to introduce a Python-based document rendering service instead

I’m not looking for language preference opinions, but for practical guidance based on memory behavior, PDF internals, and production workloads.
